text: when it comes to managing free time, i definitely prefer making detailed plans in advance rather than being spontaneous. planning allows me to make the most of my limited holidays and achieve meaningful relaxation.

first, having a clear schedule helps me visit family members i rarely see during busy school terms. without a plan, i might waste the first few days doing nothing and then feel rushed at the end. knowing exactly when to meet each person brings me real happiness and reduces last-minute stress.

second, planned activities often turn out better in quality. for example, booking tickets early for museums or outdoor trips ensures good weather and avoids long queues. spontaneous decisions sometimes lead to closed venues or bad traffic that ruin the whole day.
of course, i always leave some flexible hours for unexpected opportunities, but the basic framework of a plan gives me both structure and peace of mind during precious breaks.
i prefer making plans that stretch far into the future instead of just the next few months.
a big-picture goal keeps me motivated and gives me direction when things get tough day-to-day.
still, i always leave room to adjust because life is unpredictable, and great opportunities often come out of nowhere.

i believe weekends should be spent relaxing instead of doing work or extra tasks. after five intense weekdays, people need time to recharge both body and mind. sleeping in, reading for pleasure, or simply doing nothing helps reduce stress and prevents burnout. keeping weekends busy defeats the whole purpose of having a break.
some say people today spend too much time on fun and too little on duties. i disagree. two reasons.

first, we actually work more than ever. studies show longer office hours plus smartphones make us answer emails at home. i work 9-to-5 but average eight overtime hours weekly to serve my company and family. almost everyone at my bank does the same. our parents rarely worked weekends.

second, even leisure often includes self-improvement. many choose marathon training or gym workouts. i spend free time exercising because it keeps me healthy for parenting and work. enjoyment and duty overlap.
in sum, people today prioritize serious obligations and even turn hobbies into useful growth.
i am definitely a night person. staying up late and waking up later perfectly matches my energy level and lifestyle.
my mind works best after ten in the evening. i can focus longer, solve problems faster, and feel more creative when everyone else is asleep.
most social activities—parties, live music, late dinners with friends—happen at night. if i forced myself to wake up at six, i would be exhausted by evening and miss all the fun.
luckily, my job allows flexible hours, so i can sleep until ten or eleven and still finish everything. listening to my natural rhythm keeps me happier and more productive.
i personally prefer making plans for the distant future rather than just the next few months.
having a five- or ten-year vision gives me clear direction and keeps me motivated even when daily life gets tough.
at the same time, i stay flexible because unexpected chances often appear, and being too rigid can make you miss great opportunities.
all companies should switch to a four-day work week with no pay cut. two reasons.
first, workers get more done in less time. microsoft japan tried it—productivity rose 40% because people wasted less time and took fewer sick days.
second, happier employees stay longer. burnout is making millions quit. three days off means real rest, better mental health, and lower hiring costs for companies.
in sum, everyone wins with shorter weeks.
i like a mixture: careful planning for some free-time activities and total spontaneity for others.

planning ensures i actually do the things i’m excited about — buying tickets, preparing food for a picnic, inviting friends — instead of wasting half the day deciding. yet sometimes the best memories come from walking out the door with no plan and seeing where the day takes you.
my favorite system is to plan one day of the weekend in detail and leave the other completely open. that gives me both efficiency and delightful surprises.
whenever i get money i automatically save part of it but also spend on things that create memories.
savings give me safety and let me plan for bigger goals like grad school or travel.
at the same time, concerts, trips with friends, or a nice dinner are worth it because experiences make life richer than stuff.
my personal rule has always been 'save for a rainy day.' whenever i have extra money, i put it in the bank instead of spending it immediately because i know large expenses are waiting in the future.

university is extremely expensive. even with scholarships, i will have to cover tuition, housing, textbooks, and daily costs. spending everything now would make it impossible to pay for college later.
regular travel between home and school, especially long-distance flights, is another major expense i must prepare for. plane tickets are never cheap, and i want to visit my family for holidays.

unexpected emergencies can also happen. sudden medical bills or the need to help a family member can appear without warning. having savings gives me security and peace of mind. therefore, saving is always the wiser choice.
on weekends i prefer a mix of complete rest and light social activities.
friday night and saturday morning i usually sleep in and do nothing demanding so my brain can recover from the week.
then in the afternoon or evening i meet friends or do something fun — this balance makes me ready and energetic for monday.
i try to save a portion of any money i get, but i also allow myself to spend on experiences.
having savings gives me security and peace of mind for emergencies or future goals.
at the same time, spending on travel, concerts, or good meals with friends creates memories that are worth more than money.

i would choose the lower-paying job with regular hours. maintaining balance between work and personal life matters more than extra money. overtime exhausts people and harms health, while fixed hours allow rest, hobby development, and prevent sudden illnesses caused by overwork.

some people love constant change and new adventures, while others feel most comfortable when everything stays predictable. i used to belong to the first group, but nowadays i strongly prefer a steady routine.

in my teenage years and early twenties, i hated planning. summers meant spontaneous road trips, last-minute decisions, and meeting new people every week. that lifestyle brought excitement and taught me flexibility and openness.

everything changed after i had children. young kids need consistency to feel safe and happy. fixed bedtime, regular meals, and predictable weekends make our whole family calmer. friends also know when we’re free, which makes social life easier.
my personality didn’t really change; my circumstances did. responsibilities forced me to value stability more than adventure. a calm routine is now what feels most rewarding.
long hours for high pay often steal moments with loved ones.
more family time usually brings greater happiness than extra money.
world changed since parents' youth. my lifestyle better than theirs. two reasons.

first, my generation has more free time for fulfillment, passions. longer vacations, paid time off, shorter days than parents. i get five weeks off yearly, schedule as wanted. pursue travel, visited all continents while employed. parents traveled post-retirement, limited by age.

second, more chances for women, minorities now. past, hard for disadvantaged to succeed. now easier. as woman, encouraged university, work. mother expected homemaking, discouraged from business dreams. her case shows why my life better.
in sum, easier, better life now with more leisure, opportunities for women.

i usually sleep late on saturday morning and do almost nothing so i can fully recover from the week.
then in the afternoon or evening i meet people or do something fun; this mix leaves me refreshed for monday classes.
everyone needs at least one hobby that has zero connection to work or school.
after hours of classes and deadlines, doing something completely different like cooking, dancing, or photography lets my brain truly rest.
it reduces stress, boosts my mood, and surprisingly makes me much more productive when i go back to studying.
when it comes to free time, i prefer a balanced approach: i loosely plan the big activities but leave room for spontaneity.
detailed plans reduce stress and make sure i actually do the things i enjoy, but being too rigid kills the joy of unexpected adventures with friends or sudden inspiration.
i prefer attending parties rather than hosting them myself.
organizing an event takes so much effort: choosing a venue, cooking, decorating, and making sure everyone has fun. as a student, i simply don't have that much time or energy.
when i just attend, i can relax, enjoy the food and music, and focus on talking to friends without worrying about whether everything is going well.
stress affects health, personality, relationships. identify cause first, then apply antidotes depending on it. common types: work, friends, self.
work stress easiest: stop working briefly. if handling same paper repeatedly without progress, blame stress. talk to colleagues about non-work or walk for air. cure by escaping work.
friends stress harder; causes complicated like their problems causing anxiety or anger. cure by talking and being together; cannot walk away.
self-caused stress tough, like exam worry or future anxiety. little to do but accept best effort and leave to fate.
lead stress-free life by walking away (work), talking (friends), or facing (self). benefits health, personality, relationships.
i believe borrowing money from a friend almost always damages the relationship, even if everything goes perfectly.
the moment you ask, the friendship stops being equal. your friend may feel forced to say yes to avoid hurting you, yet secretly resent the pressure.
setting a clear repayment date feels rude, but not setting one creates anxiety. interest is even more uncomfortable to discuss.
if unexpected problems arise and you need more time, every meeting becomes awkward because the unpaid debt hangs in the air.
banks exist for exactly this purpose. keeping money separate from friendship is usually the safest way to protect both the cash and the relationship.

early mornings give quiet hours, fresh energy, and time for exercise.
starting the day with sunrise feels healthier and more organized.
i fit workouts into free time, not every day.
a full gym session takes hours with travel and recovery, hard amid classes and tasks.
saving it for weekends works better without daily rush.
i much prefer having short breaks between classes rather than one long break at the end of the day.
after a 50-minute class my brain needs at least 10 minutes to relax — grab coffee, go to the bathroom, or just breathe. these tiny pauses help me stay focused for the next lesson.
if all classes are back-to-back and i only get a long break at the end, i'll be exhausted and unable to concentrate in the later classes. it's neither efficient nor humane.

high schools should start no earlier than 9:00 a.m. two scientific reasons.
first, teenagers’ body clocks are shifted later than adults’. melatonin is released around 11 p.m. and stops at 8 a.m. asking a 14-year-old to wake at 6 a.m. is like asking an adult to wake at 3 a.m.
second, experiments prove later starts raise grades and cut depression. seattle delayed start by one hour—math scores rose 12%, car accidents by teens fell 17%, and mood improved dramatically.
in sum, biology and evidence both say: let teenagers sleep.
i function much better when i go to bed early and wake up early.
my brain is sharpest in the morning, so i get my hardest studying done before noon.
staying up late makes me tired and unfocused the next day, no matter how much coffee i drink.

going to bed early and waking up early is much better than staying up late. sleeping before 11 pm helps the body repair itself and keeps hormones balanced. people who follow this schedule have more energy during the day, better concentration, and lower risk of depression. late nights destroy natural body rhythm and make mornings painful.

money easily destroys even the strongest friendship because it creates an unequal power relationship: one person becomes debtor, the other creditor.
even if the borrower has good intentions, delays in repayment or repeated requests create discomfort, suspicion, and resentment.
many lifelong friendships have ended over relatively small amounts of money. the safest rule is: never mix money and close friendship unless you are prepared to lose one of them.

i strongly support donating money or time to people in need. when celebrities i admire publicly donate to disaster relief or education funds, it encourages thousands of fans to contribute as well.
even small donations add up. i regularly give away clothes i no longer wear and volunteer at local food banks. doing these things makes me feel more connected to society and spreads positive energy.

people should never borrow money from friends. even small amounts can destroy relationships when repayment is late or forgotten. money issues create awkwardness and resentment that years of friendship cannot fix. it is always safer to borrow from banks or family who have clearer boundaries.

i like making friends with people of different ages rather than only my peers.
older friends have more life experience and can give valuable advice about work, relationships, or tough decisions. their stories help me avoid common mistakes.
younger friends keep me updated on new trends, music, and social media. chatting with them makes me feel energetic and prevents me from becoming too serious or out of touch.
i prefer having a large circle of friends rather than just one or two close ones.

with many friends, someone is usually available when i need support or want to celebrate. different personalities keep life interesting — each person reacts uniquely to situations and teaches me new ways to handle problems. i learn far more about human nature from a diverse group than from a tiny, predictable circle.
a big friend group also means more shared experiences, ideas, and fun. i want as many teachers and companions as possible on this journey called life.

on the other hand, most people feel happier and more energetic when surrounded by friends. sharing laughter, stories, and support creates a sense of belonging and reduces loneliness.
personally, i enjoy a balance, but i slightly prefer spending time with a small circle of close friends because deep conversations and shared experiences bring me the greatest joy.

the best way i learn anything is by doing it myself.

books and lectures provide theory, but real understanding arrives only when my hands and body are involved. riding a bicycle, cooking a dish, or coding a program — no amount of reading or listening matches the immediate feedback and muscle memory that come from active practice.
doing keeps me alert and forces me to solve real problems on the spot. for me, experience is the shortest and surest path to mastery.
movies are loved almost everywhere because they offer a quick way to escape from daily stress.
within two hours, people can travel to another world, experience adventure, fall in love, or laugh without any real risk.
modern special effects make stories feel real and exciting, which books or radio cannot match.
watching films with friends or family also creates shared emotions and topics to talk about later.
friends who are similar to us feel comfortable immediately – same taste in music, same sense of humor, same values – so conversations flow easily and conflicts are rare.
friends who are different bring fresh perspectives, teach us new skills, and pull us out of our comfort zone. an introvert learns to socialize, a careful person learns to take risks.
i personally prefer a mix, but if i must choose, i value friends who are different from me more, because they help me grow and keep life interesting.
reading novels and short stories is more enjoyable and rewarding than watching movies because it keeps the imagination active.
when you read, you create the pictures, voices, and emotions in your mind. watching a film gives you everything ready-made; you just sit and receive.
regular reading trains the brain to build richer inner worlds. the more you read, the stronger and more colorful your imagination becomes.
movies are fun as a shared social event, but reading is a deeper, personal journey into an imaginary world that belongs only to you.

having a few close friends is far better than knowing many people superficially. close friends truly understand and support you during difficult times, while acquaintances disappear when you need real help. deep relationships built over years are more valuable than hundreds of shallow social media contacts.
i prefer friends who are different from me, though i also value a few who are very similar.

different friends expand my world — they introduce new music, foods, opinions, and ways of solving problems. a calm friend balances my impatience; an organized friend teaches me structure. similar friends provide comfortable understanding and shared tastes when i just want to relax without explaining myself.
the ideal is many varied acquaintances for growth and excitement plus a small core of similar close friends for deep trust and ease. best of both worlds.
comedy movies are valuable because they train us to laugh at life's small failures instead of getting angry.
after watching a good comedy, everyday problems suddenly seem less serious.
laughing together with friends in a cinema also creates happy memories and stronger relationships.
in difficult times, this ability to find humor helps people stay mentally healthy.
i prefer letting students pick their own reading materials instead of following a fixed list.
when you read what you like, you're more motivated and actually remember more. students discover new interests in fiction, history, or science that a required list might never show them.
with heavy coursework, free reading time is precious. choosing books you love makes it a real break instead of another assignment.
watching movies from other countries always reminds me how similar humans are despite different languages and traditions.

for example, a family drama from india showed parents sacrificing everything for their children’s education. scenes of mothers checking homework late at night felt exactly like my own childhood. another film from brazil had kids playing soccer in the street after school—the same excitement and teamwork i remember from my neighborhood.

work appears in almost every movie too. a story from japan followed a young office worker staying late to finish projects, while a russian film showed farmers repairing machines before sunrise. different jobs, same pride in doing them well.
celebrations also look familiar. whether people dance at weddings in nigeria or share huge meals during holidays in italy, the happiness of being together shines through.

these films prove that underneath different clothes and customs, people everywhere want their children to succeed, work with dignity, and enjoy time with loved ones. movies shrink the world and make everyone feel like neighbors.
online friends can never fully replace real-life friends. two big differences.
first, you cannot hug a screen when you cry. when my grandfather died, my neighbor brought food and sat with me for hours. discord voice chat felt empty.
second, real friends prove loyalty with actions. last month my car broke down at midnight. my childhood friend drove forty minutes to pick me up. an online friend can only type “hope you’re okay.”
in sum, flesh-and-blood friends are irreplaceable.
a small circle of close friends usually offers deeper trust and more meaningful interactions than a large group of acquaintances.
people tend to open up more easily with those they truly know, which creates stronger emotional bonds and reliable support during tough times.
on the other hand, having many different friends exposes someone to a wider range of ideas and experiences, helping personal growth and broader understanding.
in my view, quality matters more than quantity. a few genuine friendships provide the kind of loyalty and comfort that cannot be replaced by hundreds of casual contacts.
children who lose interest should be allowed to quit formal music classes.
forcing them to continue when they're bored wastes time and money and can make them hate the instrument completely.
many kids, like me with guitar, come back to it later on their own terms and actually improve faster because they choose to play songs they love.
i would definitely recommend my favorite traditional food to international friends. it brings back so many warm childhood memories because my whole family makes it together during holidays.

not only does it taste amazing, but it also carries deep cultural meaning and represents good luck in my country. sharing it with others helps them understand our traditions better and creates happy moments around the table.

past generations had few choices, but today games and videos are instant escapes.
with work and life pressures, quick shows beat the effort of pages.
music is important to almost everyone because it connects us both to other people and to our own feelings.
from childhood songs to national anthems, music strengthens the sense of belonging to a group or country.
we play special songs at weddings, funerals, victories, and protests; they become the soundtrack of collective memory.
on a personal level, certain songs instantly bring back the emotions of first love, heartbreak, or achievement.
few things can express or awaken feelings as quickly and powerfully as music does.
good neighbors make a neighborhood feel safe and pleasant. the three qualities i value most are respect, helpfulness, and friendliness.

respect means keeping noise down, not blocking someone’s driveway, and minding personal boundaries. helpfulness shows up in small ways—watching a package, lending a tool, or checking on an elderly person during bad weather.

being friendly doesn’t mean you have to be best friends; a simple greeting or short chat over the fence is enough to build trust. when neighbors have these qualities, the whole community becomes warmer and more supportive.
a good neighbor makes daily life easier and provides genuine support during difficult moments.

they show understanding about small accidental disturbances, respect property boundaries, and are willing to lend a hand—whether it's sharing ingredients, watching children, or offering a ride when needed.
in times of crisis, such as illness or loss, they step up with practical help and emotional support. having considerate, trustworthy people living nearby turns a simple address into a real community.
music plays an irreplaceable role in most people's lives for several key reasons.
first, it serves as a powerful tool for expressing and regulating emotions. a sad song can help people release grief, while upbeat music lifts mood instantly.
second, music accompanies almost every daily activity: studying, exercising, driving, or celebrating. it sets the atmosphere and makes ordinary moments more enjoyable.
lastly, listening to or playing music stimulates creativity and reduces stress, which explains why so many people say they cannot imagine life without it.
living with a roommate becomes much easier when both people are considerate and honest with each other.
a good roommate keeps shared spaces clean, respects quiet hours, and is willing to share notes or supplies when needed, and talks openly if something bothers them instead of letting problems grow.

healthy competition in studies can also be positive—seeing your roommate work hard can push you to do the same—but it should never turn into jealousy. with mutual respect and small daily kindnesses, sharing a room can even turn into a real friendship.
i prefer in-person job interviews over phone ones.
face-to-face shows expressions and gestures, making communication clearer and more confident.
it also lets me see the office space, helping decide if it fits my style.
the travel is worth it for that real feel.
people should read both fiction and non-fiction; limiting ourselves only to factual books would make life poorer.
novels and stories develop imagination and empathy by letting us walk in someone else’s shoes.
a balanced reader becomes both knowledgeable about reality and emotionally intelligent – two qualities no society can have too much of.
attending a live concert, play, or match is much more exciting than watching it on television.
the energy from thousands of people cheering or holding their breath together cannot travel through a screen.
you feel the drum in your chest, smell the grass, and react with the crowd in the same second.
television is more comfortable and has replays, but it removes the unique feeling of 'being there' that makes live events unforgettable.
i think it’s important for university students to follow the news every day.
knowing what’s happening in the world makes classroom discussions richer and helps us connect theory to real life.
even ten minutes in the morning is enough — it keeps you informed without taking too much study time.
reading fiction is far more enjoyable than watching the movie version for me.
when i read, i can decide how fast or slow the story goes, and i create the faces, voices, and scenery in my own mind.
books usually contain many more details and inner thoughts that movies have to cut because of time limits.
a film may be beautiful, but it is always someone else's imagination; a novel becomes truly mine.

the way people treat us often changes depending on what we wear, and that treatment can affect how we act in return. clothes themselves don’t change our personality, but they change the reactions we receive.

in professional settings, everyone expects suits or neat outfits. a lawyer in jeans would look unreliable, just like a mechanic in a tuxedo would seem out of place. we instantly judge competence by appearance.

once i walked into an expensive store wearing an old army jacket. the staff followed me around suspiciously, so i became extra polite to prove i wasn’t a thief. my behavior changed only because their attitude did.
clothes are a kind of social signal. when we match the expected image, people treat us with respect, and we feel confident. when we don’t, we either adjust our behavior or feel uncomfortable.
i strongly prefer spending significant time alone rather than constantly being with friends.

solitude lets me think deeply about my goals and plan how to reach them without distractions. it’s also the only way i can truly relax and lower stress through meditation or simple silence. too much social time fills my head with noise and other people’s opinions.
being alone helps me see my life clearly, without worrying about what others think i should want or do. friends are important, but regular solitude is what keeps me balanced and growing as a person.

people often form quick opinions based on how someone looks, but these judgments are often shallow and unreliable. clothing, hairstyle, or even posture can suggest certain traits, yet they reveal almost nothing about a person’s true character or values.

a person who appears unattractive might possess exceptional kindness and integrity, while someone who looks perfect on the outside can be selfish or dishonest. real qualities such as honesty, empathy, and wisdom can only be discovered through longer interaction.

society places huge value on physical attractiveness, which explains the massive beauty and fashion industries. however, beauty standards are temporary and fade with age, whereas inner qualities grow stronger and more valuable over time.
therefore, judging someone solely by appearance is unfair and often leads to wrong conclusions. true worth lies beneath the surface.

i would definitely prefer the university to assign my roommate rather than choosing one myself. getting a random person is actually part of the real college experience — it forces you to meet someone you might never pick on your own and opens the door to unexpected friendships.

the housing office already has detailed information about majors, hobbies, sleeping habits, and cleanliness levels, so their matching system is usually pretty reliable. if it turns out to be a bad fit, i can always change next semester. choosing by myself would require weeks of emails and interviews, and even then i might end up with someone who looks perfect on paper but is impossible to live with.

more importantly, rooming with someone completely different — maybe from another country or with opposite interests — pushes personal growth. staying only with people who are just like me would feel safe but boring. i came to university to expand my horizons, so i’m happy to let fate decide my roommate.

dance plays a central role in almost every culture around the world, and i strongly agree that it is far more than simple entertainment.

from ancient times, people have used dance to express emotions that words cannot capture—joy, grief, love, or spiritual connection. cave paintings over 30,000 years old already show dancing figures in religious ceremonies.

in many societies, traditional dances preserve history and identity. they pass down stories of migration, battles, harvests, and courtship from one generation to the next. when young people perform these dances, they connect directly with their ancestors.

dance also strengthens community bonds. whether at weddings, festivals, or religious events, moving together to music creates powerful feelings of unity and shared experience that strengthen social ties.
i really love having a dog at home even when everyone is busy. my dog is like a true family member who greets me excitedly every day after class and makes the house feel less empty.

taking care of him teaches me responsibility, like walking him daily and feeding him on time. whenever i feel stressed, playing with him instantly cheers me up. so for me, having a pet dog is totally worth it.
personally, i like tuning into tunes because it distracts from surrounding chaos.
it can mute annoying sounds like vehicles or chats. plus, music lifts spirits and vitality, useful for long trips.
ultimately, it's personal choice when commuting, but i find music makes me feel secure and at ease.
choosing a known friend as roommate avoids most personality clashes.
shared habits and study fields make helping each other natural.
i disagree that good friends automatically make the best roommates.
friendship and living together are different. you might love hanging out with someone but hate their messiness, late nights, or smoking habits.
the key to good roommates is matching daily routines and respect for shared space, not just being close friends.

change feels constant and sometimes frightening, yet each generation adapts. the future will belong to those who stay curious and flexible.
the single biggest change of the twentieth century that deserves to be remembered forever is the birth and explosive growth of the internet.

in less than thirty years we went from huge computers used only by governments to billions of people carrying the world's knowledge in their pockets. today a student in a remote village can watch the same university lecture as someone in new york.

the internet has shrunk the world, made information almost free, and given ordinary people voices they never had before. it has also created challenges like privacy and fake news, but overall it has made humanity more connected and knowledgeable than at any previous time in history. this revolution changed everything and will shape the future for centuries to come.
i believe that television holds a greater influence in modern society compared to books, primarily due to its accessibility and immediate impact.

firstly, television's audio-visual format makes it accessible to a wide audience, including those who may not have strong literacy skills. this inclusivity allows television to reach a broader demographic, disseminating information and ideas to a larger section of society. for example, news broadcasts on tv can instantly deliver important global events to millions of viewers, regardless of their educational background, making it a powerful medium for shaping public opinion.

secondly, the visual nature of television creates a more immediate and emotional connection with viewers. the use of images, sound, and storytelling in tv programs can convey complex ideas and narratives in a way that is both engaging and easy to understand. this can have a profound effect on viewers' perceptions and opinions. for instance, a documentary on television about environmental issues can have a more immediate emotional impact than a book on the same topic, leading to quicker public awareness and action.

lastly, the ability of television to adapt to digital trends enhances its relevance and reach. with the integration of digital platforms like streaming services, television content is now more accessible than ever, allowing it to compete effectively in the digital age and maintain its influential role in society.

in our evolving digital era, it is paramount to position digital literacy and technology courses as central components of adult lifelong education. the rapid pace at which technology progresses has left numerous adults feeling outpaced, often finding it challenging to familiarize themselves with the newest digital tools and platforms that have become integral parts of our lives.

prioritizing digital literacy does more than just simplifying daily tasks. it plays a pivotal role in professional development. it empowers adults, offering them enhanced opportunities within the contemporary job market.

moreover, this educational focus isn't merely about grasping the digital tools of today. it is an investment in the future. as technology continues its inexorable march forward, individuals equipped with a solid foundation in digital literacy will be better prepared to adapt, evolve, and harness the potential of future tech advancements.

while keeping up with technology is important for national defense and economic competitiveness, i believe government money should first solve basic social needs instead of pouring everything into computer development.

millions of people still struggle with poverty, crumbling roads, and broken bridges. fixing these problems — job training, childcare support, infrastructure repair — would improve daily life for far more citizens than another faster microchip. private companies are already excellent at creating new tech; they don’t need taxpayer money as urgently as homeless shelters or public schools do.
in the short term, human lives matter more than processing speed. once basic needs are met, then we can comfortably invest more in advanced technology.
advanced communication and transportation have connected countries more closely than ever before.
people now share music, fashion, food, and ideas almost instantly across borders.
while some fear this creates a single global culture, local traditions continue to exist and even spread worldwide through the same tools.
technology acts as a bridge that can both unite and preserve diversity at the same time.
media is like a mirror that shows a country's economic level, political bias, and social dreams.
the topics that appear most often in news and entertainment reveal what people care about or worry about.
heavy advertising of luxury goods suggests a consumer society; many reports about protests reflect political tension.
even the style of music or fashion that becomes popular through media tells us which values are rising or falling.
a company should choose to support the arts over protecting the environment because art plays a vital role in everyday life and society.
art can inspire people, build community bonds, and highlight various social issues. it reflects religious, political, and economic elements of cultures.
art involves everyone, from creators to audiences, and takes many forms like architecture, clothing, and sculptures. it mirrors nature, organizes chaos, and enhances human experiences.
art offers pleasure, intellectual stimulation, imagination boosts, storytelling, and historical records. it is essential to life itself.

i firmly believe that the differences among people from different countries are indeed diminishing due to the increasing global exposure and interchange of cultural products and ideas. this globalization, characterized by the widespread availability of diverse cultural elements, significantly narrows the perceived gap between different societies.

firstly, the global food culture is a prime example. the ability to enjoy a wide variety of international cuisines in almost any part of the world fosters a shared culinary experience. for instance, sushi, originally a japanese dish, is now a global phenomenon, relished in diverse countries. this mutual appreciation of different cuisines creates common ground among people from various backgrounds.

secondly, the universal appeal of certain entertainment forms, especially movies and music, has a unifying effect. hollywood movies, bollywood songs, and korean pop music have fans across the globe, transcending national borders. this shared entertainment culture bridges gaps and fosters a sense of global community.

lastly, the accessibility to authentic goods from around the world, as andrew mentioned, brings a piece of foreign culture into our daily lives. be it italian fashion, german automobiles, or korean electronics, the use and appreciation of these products create a sense of familiarity and connection with cultures different from our own.

in essence, the global exchange of culture, in the form of food, entertainment, and goods, plays a significant role in bringing people closer together, making our differences seem less pronounced. while deep cultural and ideological differences still exist, these shared experiences work towards creating a more interconnected and harmonious global community.
while protecting patents encourages investment in research, excessive secrecy in fundamental science ultimately slows human progress. major breakthroughs are usually built on shared knowledge.
fields like medicine have advanced fastest when findings are published openly, enabling global experts to verify, improve, and apply results immediately.
the rapid development of covid-19 vaccines demonstrated how unprecedented data-sharing across institutions and countries saved millions of lives in record time.
therefore, non-commercial discoveries should be disclosed promptly, with intellectual property protection limited to specific applications rather than basic principles.

community reading centers continue to play a vital role by hosting events that promote literacy and social interaction, compensating for the limitations of online collections. these hubs foster inclusive environments where diverse groups can exchange ideas freely.

beyond mere storage, they organize workshops and discussions that enrich cultural understanding and support lifelong learning. such initiatives bridge gaps left by virtual platforms, especially for those without reliable internet.
preserving these spaces ensures equitable access to knowledge, strengthening societal ties and inspiring curiosity across generations.
governments should invest heavily in computer technology as it boosts efficiency and provides vast resources for decision-making.
computers save time by reducing paperwork and manpower in offices, allowing employees to complete tasks quicker and handle more projects.
automated systems like payroll minimize manual input, potentially cutting staff needs and company costs.
leaders gain quick access to data for faster decisions, with controlled privacy levels for different groups.
money is necessary, but it is rarely the main reason people keep working at the same place for years. most stay because they actually enjoy what they do.
many jobs let you see the direct result of your effort. teachers watch students improve, engineers see bridges they designed being used, doctors save lives. that feeling is priceless.
work also gives structure to the day and a sense of belonging. being part of a team, solving problems together, and receiving recognition from colleagues motivates people far more than a paycheck.
in short, people work for personal fulfillment, social connection, and the satisfaction of making a difference—not just to pay bills.
no one is perfect in every area, so when facing major decisions such as choosing a career, buying a house, or getting married, it is wise to ask for advice from experienced people.
family members, mentors, or friends who have been through similar situations can offer new perspectives and help spot risks we might miss when we are too emotionally involved.
of course, the final choice should still be your own, but listening to different opinions usually leads to better and more balanced decisions.

a person should never make an important decision alone. decisions need thorough thought. close people know what is best and can offer advice, different perspectives, or share experiences.
when deciding college classes, talked to teachers and advisors. their expertise helped choose suitable courses for the future career. without advice, might have picked wrong ones.

in college, thought not good enough for the school play and decided not to audition despite passion for drama. a friend questioned this and provided another view on talents. rethought, auditioned, and got a lead role.
when deciding on studying overseas, talked to a friend who had done it. she shared challenges and opportunities, helping make the right choice. went abroad and it was amazing.
for important decisions, seek others' advice to be well-informed and benefit from their perspectives and experiences.
i prefer to stick to things i already do well instead of constantly trying risky new activities. focusing on my strengths brings me better results and less stress.

when i was younger i tried many hobbies—painting, dancing, coding—but i was average at all of them. once i concentrated only on writing, my skills improved quickly and i started earning money from it.
mastering one area gives a real sense of achievement. world-class experts became great because they practiced the same thing for thousands of hours, not because they kept switching interests.
life is short. i would rather be outstanding at one thing that i love than mediocre at ten different things.
i completely agree that people learn more from failure than from instant success.
when things go wrong, you’re forced to analyze what happened, fix your approach, and build resilience.
most successful people i admire have a long list of failures behind them — that’s exactly where they gained the real experience.
natural talent can open doors, but hard work decides who stays successful. in sports, school, and business, i have seen effort beat raw ability almost every time.
many gifted athletes never reach the top because they rely only on talent and skip training. the ones who become champions practice for hours every single day.
in school, naturally smart students sometimes fail exams because they never review. classmates who study regularly, even if they learn more slowly, end up with higher grades.

great salespeople may have a natural charm, but the top earners are those who research clients, follow up carefully, and fill out paperwork perfectly. talent starts the conversation; effort closes the deal.
talent is a gift you are born with. consistent hard work is a choice you make every day. in the long run, the choice matters much more than the gift.
never make big decisions completely alone. always talk to someone. two reasons.

first, someone older has almost certainly faced the same choice. when i had to pick trade school or university my practical father surprised me: he once almost studied arts and still has regrets. his story helped me weigh both sides.

second, talking slows you down and stops rash moves. last year i bought a car the same day i saw it because gas was cheap. my classmate reminded me prices always rise and parking is easy only in summer. i regretted not discussing first.
in sum, advice from others brings wisdom and prevents impulsive mistakes.

the saying 'never give up' encourages people to continue pursuing their dreams no matter how many times they fail. i completely agree with this idea because life always offers new chances and different ways to reach the same destination.

when i was in high school, i ran for class president and lost badly in the first attempt. instead of feeling defeated, i analyzed my mistakes and worked harder the next year by preparing speeches and talking to more classmates. eventually, i won the election. this experience taught me that one failure does not mean the end.

another time, i dreamed of becoming a doctor, but i struggled terribly with chemistry and biology. rather than giving up on helping people, i switched my major to psychology, where i could still make a difference in people's lives in a different way. changing direction is not the same as quitting.

even in small daily situations, there is always another option. once i needed to contact a friend urgently, but his phone was dead and email was not working. instead of waiting, i took a bus across the city to meet him in person. persistence finds a way.
giving up too early closes all doors. as long as we stay determined and flexible, there will always be another opportunity waiting.
when actors, singers, or athletes express their views on social or political issues, i believe ordinary people should not blindly follow them.

being excellent at sports or entertainment does not automatically make someone knowledgeable about climate change, economics, or international relations. a basketball player may be a genius on the court, but that does not mean his opinion on tax policy is more valuable than a professor’s.

however, celebrities do have the power to raise awareness quickly. when they speak about topics they truly understand, such as mental health or racial discrimination they have personally experienced, their voice can educate millions and push society forward.
in short, we should listen selectively: respect their influence, but always think critically instead of treating every word from a famous mouth as truth.
when i face a hard decision i always talk to someone older and wiser. two reasons.

first, most problems are not unique. someone has already lived it. as freshman i couldn’t decide between trade school and university. talking to my practical father i learned even he once considered liberal arts and had regrets. his story helped me think clearly.
second, just saying the problem aloud reduces drama. last week i fought with my girlfriend over $50. explaining it to my dad made me realize it was tiny and we would get over it fast.
in sum, experienced people give both precedent and calm perspective.
i truly believe we learn way more from failing than from getting everything right the first time.
failure forces you to examine your mistakes, change your strategy, and come back stronger.
almost every successful person i know has a long string of failures; those are the real lessons that turn them into experts.
when i face important decisions i usually ask my parents first, but i also value my friends’ opinions.
parents have more life experience and can warn me about long-term consequences i might not see.
friends understand my current situation and feelings better, so combining both gives me the clearest picture.
sticking only to what we master feels safe and predictable.
trying unknown things brings excitement, growth, and sometimes big rewards.
a little courage to fail keeps life interesting and skills sharp.
although money is the primary reason most people work, it is far from the only motivation.

many individuals value independence more than a high salary. once young people leave school, they want to make their own decisions, support a family, and turn their knowledge into a real business rather than always follow someone else's orders.

others are drawn to non-financial rewards. company perks such as discounted products, free travel for employees, or flexible hours often feel more valuable than extra cash and help companies attract talent.

a significant number of workers choose their career because they genuinely love what they do. teachers, doctors, artists, and charity workers often accept lower pay because the job itself brings deep personal fulfillment.
finally, long-term security matters. as people get older, a good retirement plan and health insurance become major factors when deciding whether to join or stay with an employer.
success comes from a combination of bold action and careful preparation. pure luck is rare; most successful people plan thoroughly and then dare to take the necessary risks.
every big achievement starts with a detailed plan. entrepreneurs write business plans, athletes follow training schedules, students make study timetables. planning reduces unnecessary failure.
however, no plan survives first contact with reality. successful people stay flexible—they notice new possibilities and change direction when needed.
in the end, those who prepare well and still have the courage to act when the moment comes are the ones who reach their goals.

many believe that huge salaries and luxury possessions equal success. although money certainly improves life quality, i disagree that earning a lot is the only measure of achievement. true success is deeper and more varied.
philosophically, success is about inner qualities such as kindness, integrity, and empathy rather than bank account size. a wealthy but cruel person cannot be considered truly successful.

socially, how we treat others matters far more than material wealth. someone who supports friends, respects colleagues, and contributes to the community achieves a different but valuable kind of success.

personally, each individual defines success differently according to their own background and dreams. for one person it might be raising happy children, for another starting a charity, and for someone else reaching the top of their profession.
therefore, success has countless faces. reducing it only to money ignores the richness of human experience and the many ways people create meaningful lives.
forming a final opinion about someone after one meeting is unfair and often inaccurate. people deserve time before we decide who they really are.
quick judgment saves time when you meet hundreds of people, but it can make us miss great friendships or opportunities. everyone has off days.
i often feel nervous or say the wrong thing when meeting someone new. if others judged me only by that moment, they would get a completely wrong picture.
taking time to know someone shows respect and openness. beneath the surface, most people have much more to offer than what we see at first glance.
if i had the opportunity to ask one question to any famous person, i would ask: 'when you face major setbacks or feel completely lost, what keeps you going?'
everyone, no matter how successful, experiences failure, criticism, or exhaustion. hearing how a well-known figure finds inner strength during dark times would be very valuable.
their answer might reveal a belief, a memory, or a habit that ordinary people can also use. that single piece of wisdom could change how i handle my own difficulties.
everyone has to do things they don't enjoy sometimes. this is part of being a responsible adult and can even lead to unexpected benefits.
daily chores like visiting the dentist, doing taxes, or cleaning are never fun, but they are necessary for health and order.
at work, we often face boring assignments or difficult colleagues. dealing with them professionally is required to keep a job and income.

interestingly, doing something we think we hate can sometimes change our mind. trying a new food or activity we avoided may turn into a new pleasure. therefore, stepping outside our comfort zone is valuable even when the task itself is not enjoyable.
success is not only about money and titles. true success is feeling satisfied with your life. two reasons.
first, many rich people are miserable. my uncle owns three companies but never sees his children and takes sleeping pills every night. he calls himself a failure.
second, ordinary jobs can bring deep happiness. my mother has been a nurse for thirty years. she comes home tired but proud because she helps people every day.
in sum, inner peace beats a big bank account.
for big choices, i always ask family or close friends.
they know me well and offer practical views i might miss alone.
it reduces regrets and strengthens ties through sharing thoughts.
the idea that fast decisions are always wrong is simply not true. speed doesn’t equal mistake; it depends on experience and stakes.

sometimes a quick yes is actually smart. when your boss suddenly offers an important project, accepting immediately can be the right move. you trust that they picked you for a reason and see the career opportunity.
other times, fast choices can be dangerous. accepting a ride from a stranger at night just to avoid waiting might feel convenient, but safety should come first.
the key is knowing the situation. for small matters like choosing lunch, speed doesn’t matter. for life-changing moments, i prefer to take all the time i need.

many people believe self-confidence is the single most important factor for success. i think it is essential, but it is not enough by itself. real success requires confidence plus solid knowledge plus sensitivity to others.
confidence gives you the courage to try. if you believe you can pass an exam or finish a project, you will put in the effort and usually perform better.
however, confidence without knowledge is dangerous. i have seen very confident students fail because they never studied. knowledge is the foundation; confidence is the fuel.

sensitivity is equally important outside the classroom. you need to know when to speak up and when to listen, when to show off and when to be humble. reading the situation correctly often decides real-world success.
only when confidence, knowledge, and sensitivity work together do you get consistent, long-term achievement in school or at work.
i partly agree that people are rarely completely satisfied with what they have.
this restlessness pushes humanity forward—new inventions, career changes, and personal growth usually start because someone saying 'i want something better'.
however, learning to enjoy what we already have is also a skill; without it we become exhausted always chasing the next thing.
i think it's better to decide together with friends where to hang out.

if i always make the decision alone, others might feel ignored or think i'm selfish. for example, if i insist on my favorite restaurant without asking, some friends may dislike the food and feel unhappy.
discussing together shows respect and makes sure everyone feels comfortable. it's more likely that we'll all have a good time.

life throws tasks we dodge at first. kids skip books for wild chases, but skipping lessons stalls their path. talents face odd hurdles like group talks, yet pushing through opens doors. athletes test limits under rules, building grit over gripes.
for me success is not only about money or titles; it’s about feeling happy and proud of how i spend my days.
having good relationships, health, and work that feels meaningful matter way more than a big salary.
money helps, but i’ve seen plenty of rich people who are miserable and simple people who are truly content.

systems like chat tools should use kind words and proper tones in talks with users. the key reason is that one clear source of info can shape how many talks go, and rough replies might lead to bad habits or upset feelings. models such as those from big firms draw from wide data sets, but skipping soft ways of sharing can miss key social cues or lead to harsh outputs.

as a result, they might chat in ways that bother kids or push wrong paths in talks. for one case, saying blunt things to young users could spark mix-ups or hurt bonds in family settings. there, it's key to hold good start and open chats with tech to build a better space for all who use it.
excellent parents share three essential qualities: unconditional love, complete trust, and genuine respect for their children’s unique personalities.

real love does not depend on grades, career choice, or partner selection. good parents support their child even when life decisions differ from what they imagined. this security lets children take healthy risks.
trust works both ways. parents who believe their teenagers will make sensible choices receive honesty in return. constant suspicion creates distance and secrets.

respect means accepting that each child is different. some love art, others prefer sports; some want to travel, others stay close to home. the best parents encourage individual paths instead of demanding copies of themselves.
children raised with these three gifts grow confident, responsible, and kind. they know they are loved exactly as they are, free to become whoever they choose.

personal success depends more on hard work than on luck. people who consistently study, practice, and improve their skills eventually reach their goals. those who only wait for lucky breaks usually achieve little. history shows that almost all successful individuals worked extremely hard for many years.

in my view, being a leader is far better than simply following others. real leaders take the first step, make tough choices, and accept full responsibility for the results. while some team members may agree and others may complain, they all decided to follow rather than decide.

effective leaders don’t just react to problems; they foresee them and act early. for instance, a student council president who notices tension between the campus and nearby residents can create a plan to reduce noise, organize community clean-ups, and encourage students to shop locally. this kind of proactive attitude defines true leadership.

great leaders are also action-driven. once they start something, they see it through by motivating everyone involved and explaining why the effort matters. personally, i love setting the direction and owning the outcome—even if mistakes happen, i’d rather they be my own than suffer from someone else’s poor choices.
nothing beats talking to someone in person. face-to-face communication is warmer, clearer, and more effective than messages or phone calls.
you can instantly see if the other person is confused or upset and adjust your words. tone of voice, facial expressions, and gestures carry more meaning than text on a screen.
in-person conversations also last longer and go deeper. when you make the effort to meet someone, both sides pay more attention and the relationship grows stronger.
technology is convenient, but for important matters or building real trust, meeting face to face is still the best way.
everyone has to do things they dislike from time to time.
studying, awkward job interviews, or medical tests may feel bad but open better doors later.
avoiding them only limits growth and future chances.
in my opinion, the best coworkers bring three qualities: a sense of humor, strong work efficiency, and real team spirit.

someone who can lighten the mood with a joke during stressful moments makes the whole office more pleasant. at the same time, they finish their tasks quickly and accurately so the rest of the team isn’t delayed.

most importantly, they cooperate willingly—offering help when someone is overloaded and celebrating group success instead of only caring about personal credit. these characteristics make daily work enjoyable and productive.
a good boss must be able to stay calm and make sensible decisions even under pressure. the whole team depends on the leader’s judgment, so rushing or panicking can harm everyone.

equally important is treating employees with courtesy and respect. nobody enjoys working for someone who shouts or belittles others. when people feel valued, they work harder and stay longer in the company.

patience and the ability to motivate the team are also essential. a great supervisor knows how to encourage people when things go wrong, shares credit when things go well, and keeps communication open. these qualities create trust and help the whole organization succeed.
parents should guide but not make final decisions for their 15–18-year-old children.
teenagers need room to make their own choices and learn from consequences; this is how real responsibility is built.
however, parents’ greater experience means their advice is invaluable. the healthiest approach is discussion and guidance rather than orders.
i completely agree that experiences that feel painful at the time usually become valuable lessons later.
failing an important exam, losing a job, or going through a failed relationship often teaches resilience, forces self-reflection, and builds skills that easy success never could.
most accomplished people openly say their biggest breakthroughs came after their worst setbacks.
i completely disagree that only people who earn a lot of money are successful.
success is subjective. for some it means raising happy children, for others it means making a positive impact on society or achieving inner peace.
a teacher who inspires generations, a nurse who saves lives, or a parent who builds a loving home can be far more successful than a wealthy but miserable businessperson.
true success combines reasonable financial stability with personal fulfillment and good relationships.

life throws many challenges at us. to grow and succeed, we sometimes have to do things we dislike. while everyone prefers enjoyable activities, i strongly believe that handling unpleasant duties is essential. my reasons are personal, social, and practical.

on a personal level, facing tasks we dislike builds resilience and maturity. for example, new parents often lose sleep caring for a baby yet still manage work the next day. similarly, students who force themselves to study instead of going out usually earn better grades. these experiences teach discipline and make us stronger individuals.

socially, we live in a connected society that requires certain obligations. attending family events, weddings, or even funerals shows respect and care for others, even when we would rather stay home. these actions help us move beyond selfishness and strengthen community bonds.

from a practical perspective, most people work longer hours than they want to because of financial responsibilities. we need income to support families, pay bills, and save for the future. without accepting these necessary burdens, comfortable living would be impossible.
in short, doing things we do not enjoy is part of becoming a well-rounded person. both pleasant and unpleasant experiences shape who we are and help us lead richer lives.
i strongly disagree that only people who earn a lot of money are successful. real success has many other measures.
fame is one example. many respected scientists and humanitarians, like mother teresa, were not rich but changed the world.
respect from others is another sign. a poorly paid teacher or band conductor who is loved and admired by students is often more successful than a rich but disliked lawyer.
knowledge itself can be success. in the movie good will hunting, the janitor who solved difficult math problems chose a simple life yet felt fulfilled.
history remembers people who contributed to society, not those who just collected money. therefore, success is about impact and personal achievement, not only wealth.
i have mixed feelings about leaders making quick decisions without asking others.
consulting team members brings different views and avoids mistakes, leading to better results.
but in fast situations like market investments, waiting for input might mean missing chances as things change quickly.
since we spend so many hours with colleagues, having good coworkers makes work much more pleasant. in my experience, the best coworkers share several important qualities.
first, they are cooperative and team-oriented. they care about the whole team's success, not just their own tasks, and they maintain a positive attitude that improves the office atmosphere.
second, they are adaptable. they accept changes in plans or responsibilities without complaining and are willing to adjust their schedule to help others when needed.

third, they are genuinely helpful. when someone falls behind, they offer support without keeping score or expecting something in return. a good coworker strengthens the sense of community in the workplace.
running your own business gives freedom to choose direction and hours.
all risk and all reward belong to you alone.
relationships are complicated. sometimes it is better not to tell the full truth. two reasons.

first, small lies can push loved ones to do their best. people are competitive. my husband ran a marathon last year. i knew he had no chance of top ten but told him he did. the lie gave confidence; he trained hard and finished. truth might have made him quit.

second, total honesty can cause unnecessary worry. last week a coworker asked about her new haircut. i said it looked awful. she looked hurt; i spent the day anxious about our friendship and couldn’t focus. a kind lie would have saved stress.
in sum, occasional dishonesty can motivate others and protect our own peace of mind.
most humans seem unable to feel completely satisfied for long. we always notice something bigger, newer, or different that we want instead.
even small children drop a toy the moment they see another one. adults do the same with jobs, houses, cars, or clothes. comparing ourselves to others fuels this feeling.
this restlessness can be positive. wanting more drives invention, effort, and improvement. without it, societies would stagnate.
the problem appears when we can never enjoy what we already have. constant desire without moments of gratitude leaves us empty inside.
excellent supervisors share several key qualities regardless of industry: fairness, clear communication, and the ability to delegate effectively.
they treat every employee equally, give precise instructions without constant changes, and evaluate performance based on objective criteria rather than personal feelings.

most importantly, they model the work ethic and attitude they expect from their team. when employees see their boss working hard and valuing their contributions, morale and productivity naturally increase.
when i need advice on big decisions, i talk to both my parents and close friends.
parents have more life experience and can spot long-term risks i might miss.
friends understand exactly how i feel right now and what my daily life is like, so together they give me the most balanced view.
failure is the best teacher. two reasons.
first, every successful person failed many times. j.k. rowling was rejected by twelve publishers. that pain taught her to improve until harry potter became a global phenomenon.
second, easy success makes us lazy and arrogant. students who get perfect scores without effort often collapse at university because they never learned how to struggle.
in sum, falling down and standing up builds real strength.

people learn more from their mistakes than from their successes. failure forces deep reflection and permanent change, while success sometimes creates overconfidence. almost every great inventor and entrepreneur succeeded only after dozens of painful failures.
when something goes wrong with a purchase or service, i usually choose to express my dissatisfaction through a written message instead of speaking face-to-face.
writing lets me arrange my arguments clearly and calmly. i can list the exact problems and provide evidence without getting interrupted or losing my train of thought.
complaining in person often becomes emotional very quickly. anger might feel good for a second, but it rarely solves anything and can make the other person defensive.
another advantage is that a letter reaches the person who actually has the power to fix the issue. the employee standing in front of you is usually not the one responsible.
finally, sending a complaint by registered mail creates proof that i tried to resolve the matter reasonably. if further steps become necessary, i have documentation to support my case.

patience is more important than talent in achieving success. talented people who rush and give up easily fail, while patient people keep practicing and improving for years. almost every overnight success actually took a decade of quiet persistence.
i strongly disagree that decisions made quickly are always wrong.
in emergencies—fire, accident, or sudden market crash—waiting too long can be disastrous.
in everyday life, we make hundreds of fast decisions (what to eat, which route to take) that are perfectly fine.
the key is knowing when speed matters and when you should slow down and think carefully.
i believe watching a recording of my own presentation is far more effective than just asking classmates for feedback.
when you watch yourself, you notice details others might miss, such as nervous gestures, unclear pronunciation, or awkward pauses. these small issues are easier to spot objectively on video.

also, feedback from others can be biased or too polite. classmates may avoid harsh criticism to be kind, whereas a recording shows the exact truth. combining both methods is ideal, but self-review through video provides the most accurate picture for real improvement.
the main job of good parents is to love their children unconditionally and meet their basic physical, emotional, and educational needs.

parents should protect their kids from danger while teaching them how to become confident, polite, and responsible adults. this means setting reasonable rules, spending quality time together, and showing by example what it means to be a good person.
although society sometimes criticizes parents for being too strict or too lenient, most mothers and fathers simply try their best to raise happy and capable human beings.
i strongly agree with the idea of 'never, never give up'.
giving up too early robs us of the second or third chance that often leads to success.

history is full of people who succeeded only because they kept trying after everyone else would have quit—writers rejected dozens of times, inventors whose early models failed repeatedly, athletes who lost many competitions before winning gold.
face-to-face conversation is still the most effective and warmest way to communicate.

however, she may dislike the high cost of housing, constant traffic, and crowded streets. parking is difficult and everything feels busy all the time.

nature is another weak point. there are few large parks or green areas, and the sea and mountains are far away. city beauty is different from natural beauty. overall, my city is best for people who love energy and options more than peace and space.
i grew up in a small town but have lived in a big city for ten years, and now i strongly prefer city life.
public transportation in big cities is much more convenient and often cheaper than owning a car, which is almost necessary in small towns.
cities are exciting because something new is always happening—new restaurants, concerts, festivals, and people from every background imaginable.
the variety of cultures, food, and events keeps life interesting. living among people who are different from me has made me more open-minded.
small towns may be safer and quieter, but i would rather accept a little extra caution in exchange for the energy and opportunities of a big city.

living in a big city is definitely better than the countryside. cities offer endless job opportunities, top hospitals, international food, cultural events, and efficient public transport. countryside life is too quiet, isolated, and lacks the excitement and convenience that make life interesting.
big cities pack too many folks into tight spots. the air turns thick with fumes that spark breathing woes. noise and rush wear down the spirit fast.
small towns let kids roam free amid green fields. plants and critters teach lessons books can't match. close ties build trust and joy in daily life.

if i could change one big thing in my city i would build many more parks and green spaces. two reasons.

first, parks reduce stress in a concrete jungle. people here face tall grey buildings, traffic, crowds every day. my father had a minor heart attack from city stress. after retirement he moved to a green area and quickly felt happier and healthier. parks inside the city would give us the same relief.
second, green spaces encourage exercise and community. walking, jogging, picnics become daily habits when parks are close. obesity and loneliness would drop.
in sum, more parks would make my town calmer, healthier and more active.
growing up in the countryside is generally better for children than growing up in a big city.
children in rural areas play freely in nature, breathe clean air, and grow up in tight-knit communities where everyone knows and helps each other.
cities offer more museums and courses, but the stress, pollution, and danger usually outweigh those advantages for young kids.
if i were given a piece of land to use freely, i would turn it into a public campground open to everyone.

in my area, affordable outdoor activities are quite limited. most entertainment options are expensive, and there are almost no parks or sports facilities nearby. a campground would offer a low-cost way for families and friends to spend time together in nature.

camping fees are usually very reasonable, and the site could include free picnic areas, hiking trails, and basic sports fields that day visitors could use as well. people would be able to grill food, play games, swim in a small lake, or simply relax under the trees without spending much money.

more importantly, spending time outdoors promotes physical health and reduces stress. instead of sitting inside watching screens, people would walk, breathe fresh air, and stay active. a well-designed campground would make the whole community happier and healthier.

staying in private homes through platforms like airbnb has become my favorite way to travel, and i believe this trend is very positive.

first, it offers authentic local experiences that hotels cannot match. living in a real neighborhood, cooking in a local kitchen, and chatting with hosts give deeper cultural insight than staying in standardized hotel rooms.

second, private residences often provide better value and comfort. many come with full kitchens, living rooms, and multiple bedrooms, perfect for families or longer stays. travelers feel more relaxed and at home compared to the temporary feel of hotels.

first of all, the constant flow of visitors, especially during evenings and weekends, creates heavy traffic and severe parking problems. cars lining up on narrow streets not only block emergency vehicles but also release large amounts of exhaust fumes.

moreover, cinemas generate significant noise pollution. loud sound effects from multiple screens, crowds talking and laughing late at night, and car horns all destroy the peaceful atmosphere that people expect at home.

modern apartments have better plumbing, security, and weather protection.
new buildings offer more rooms and storage for different needs.

first, it kills family-run stores. when a mall opened in my parents’ small town their favorite hardware store closed. the new mall store was bigger but hired fewer, lower-paid staff.

second, malls increase car dependence and destroy walkable life. downtown shops let us walk or bike. malls force forty-minute drives. my brother lost his favorite bookstore when it moved to a distant mall. now buying one book means a long car trip.
in sum, malls hurt local jobs and make daily life less convenient.
