the main purpose of advertising is to convince us to buy things we don’t actually need. from childhood cartoons full of toy commercials to adult lifestyle ads, we are taught that happiness comes from owning the newest products.
this creates a cycle of trying to match our neighbors’ cars, gadgets, and fashion, often beyond our budget. advertising pushes shallow values based on possessions rather than personal qualities.
that said, ads do inform us about useful new products and keep the economy moving by creating jobs. therefore, although often manipulative, advertising is a necessary evil in a consumer society.
movies and television definitely influence our behavior, sometimes negatively but also in many positive ways.

watching a lot of violence can make people less sensitive to it and more accepting of aggressive behavior. it can also make us lazier because watching is passive—we stop using our imagination and prefer screen entertainment to real activities.
on the positive side, films and shows introduce us to different cultures and people, helping reduce prejudice. seeing disabled characters or interracial friendships on screen makes them feel normal.
media can also lower stress by letting us escape our problems for a while or by showing healthy ways to solve conflicts.
whether the influence is good or bad depends on what we watch and how actively we think about it.
many believe that technology influences society in various ways.
i think that internet access benefits individuals and communities greatly. i believe this for two reasons i'll discuss below.

first, online news exposes corruption and keeps leaders accountable. previously, few media outlets existed, often linked to politicians, hesitant to criticize. now, independent web sites reveal misconduct. for example, an online mag exposed my town's mayor taking bribes from a developer. the detailed report forced his resignation. though evidence was available, only this site reported it. this shows how the internet aids democracy.

second, people are more politically engaged as they share ideas online. globally, social media lets people express views. formerly, individuals felt isolated in beliefs; now they find others agree. my experience shows this. as a student, i heard a park near my home would be demolished for parking. i enjoyed the park and felt powerless alone. but i joined a facebook group against it. learning many loved the park, we protested at city hall successfully. social media gave us courage to act.
in sum, the internet positively affects lives by strengthening democracy via online news and encouraging local political involvement through social sites.

face-to-face communication is more important than online messaging. in real life, you can read tone, facial expressions, and body language, which prevents most misunderstandings. texting lacks these cues and often causes unnecessary arguments even among close friends.
advertising actually reveals a lot about what a society considers important or normal.
the products that are heavily promoted and the way people are shown using them reflect current trends and dreams.
in some countries ads focus on family happiness and tradition, while in others they emphasize individual success and luxury.
by looking at commercials, we can quickly see differences in fashion, beauty standards, and even humor between nations.
tv advertising aimed at children under 12 should be banned. two reasons.

first, young kids cannot tell the difference between programs and commercials. they believe cartoon characters who say sugar cereal is healthy. childhood obesity has tripled since such ads became common.
second, ads create endless nagging and family fights. my neighbor’s six-year-old cried for weeks because he wanted the exact toy on tv. parents feel forced to buy things they cannot afford.
in sum, protecting children from manipulation is more important than company profits.
i completely agree that newspapers, television, and magazines focus far too much on the personal lives of famous people.

first, constant coverage of who a star is dating, what they eat, or where they go on vacation has nothing to do with their professional talent. this kind of reporting turns audiences into voyeurs and reduces artists and athletes to mere gossip material.

second, endless pursuit by paparazzi seriously damages mental health and even physical safety. many celebrities cannot walk down the street or take their children to school without being photographed. such invasion of privacy often leads to anxiety, depression, and family problems.
the media should respect reasonable boundaries and let public figures keep a small private space. after all, being famous does not mean losing basic human rights.
television can have negative effects on children if parents do not control what they watch.
many programs and cartoons contain fighting or aggressive language that very young kids may copy in real life.
studies show that spending too many hours in front of screens also reduces time for reading, sports, or talking with family.
however, some channels offer excellent educational content about nature, science, and foreign languages, so the problem is not television itself but how it is used.
i don’t agree that television has destroyed communication among friends and family. it depends on the type of program and the type of viewer.
empty, mindless shows combined with passive viewers who just sit and stare can reduce conversation because people don’t feel the need to talk or think.
however, active viewers who watch interesting dramas, documentaries, or clever comedies often want to discuss what they saw with others. good programs spark ideas and debates.
television can actually improve communication when family members watch together and share their opinions afterward.
so for thoughtful viewers, television is a tool that encourages conversation rather than killing it.

some parents believe that closely monitoring their children's online activity and messages protects them from danger, while others argue this violates privacy. personally, i believe limited and transparent monitoring is acceptable and even necessary for younger teenagers.

first, the internet contains real dangers such as predators, cyberbullying, and inappropriate content. children under 16 often lack the maturity to recognize these threats. many real cases have shown on news programs demonstrate that parental awareness has prevented serious harm.

however, constant secret surveillance can destroy trust. instead, parents should have an open conversation explaining why they want to check certain apps or messages occasionally, set clear rules together, and gradually give more freedom as the child proves responsible. this balanced approach keeps children safe while respecting their growing need for independence.
although celebrities can attract huge attention, i believe that using ordinary people as spokespeople is far more effective in most advertising campaigns.

first of all, ordinary consumers tend to trust real users more than famous people who are clearly being paid large sums to promote products. when we see a celebrity holding a soft drink or wearing a watch, we automatically think, 'they're just doing it for the money.' on the other hand, when we see a regular person who looks like us saying they love the product, it feels more authentic and believable.

secondly, ordinary people are much more relatable. most of us cannot imagine living like movie stars or athletes, so their lifestyles feel distant. however, when an average parent talks about how a certain detergent removes stains from kids' clothes, or when a college student recommends an affordable laptop, the message hits closer to home.

finally, featuring ordinary people is usually far less expensive than hiring celebrities, allowing companies to run longer campaigns and show a diverse range of real customers instead of relying on one famous face.
